mdRecord.dcterms:title: War Department, January 18th, 1809: Sir, The pressure of the Embargo although sensibly felt by every description of our fellow citizens, has yet been cheerfully borne / H. Dearbourn, Secretary of War. Lebanon, 4th Feb. 1809. : Sir, I have received your letter .. conveying to me a request of the president .. that .. I would appoint a select number of officers of our Militia, to whom the collectors of the customs may apply for military aid in certain cases .. / Jonathan Trumbull

mdRecord.dcterms:description: Letter from the Secretary of War authorizing "proper persons to employ militia for preventing ... armed or riotous assemblage of persons resisting the custom-house officers ... or opposing or violating the embargo laws." With the response of Jonathan Trumbull, Gov. of Conn., that "the late law ... is unconstitutional in many of its provisions, interfereing (!) with the state sovereignties, and subversive of the guaranteed rights, privileges, and immunities of the citizens of the United States."
